message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the effects of skidding and friction. When an object skids, such as a car on a slippery road, friction is generated between the object and the surface it is skidding on. Option (A) is incorrect because when a car is rolling without skidding, the friction is minimized. Option (B) is unrelated to skidding and friction. Option (C) is also unrelated to skidding and friction. Option (D) is the correct answer because Nascar races often involve high-speed cars that skid and generate friction with the track surface.

This question pertains to the concept of skidding and friction. Skidding occurs when there is a lack of traction between a surface and an object, causing friction. Among the given options, Nascar races involve high-speed cars that often skid due to the forces acting on them. The other options do not necessarily involve skidding or friction. Option (A) is incorrect because rolling a car does not necessarily involve skidding. Option (B) is unrelated because riding a rhino does not involve a skidding motion. Option (C) is unrelated because running a track does not involve skidding as well.

This question requires basic knowledge about friction and its relationship to skidding. When a car skids, there is an increase in friction between the tires and the road. This can be observed in Nascar races, where cars are often seen skidding and sliding around the track. Option (A) is incorrect because rolling a car does not necessarily involve skidding. Option (B) is unrelated to the concept of skidding and friction. Option (C) is incorrect because running a track does not typically involve skidding.
